(I was sad to see them gone when I finally looked at a copy in a bookstore recently)
illustrations++
oh wait, is the 60% off only for the ebook?
so no illustrations and not even any dead trees?
whats not to luv
no, i expect you to buy a bag of bits with no illustrations
mpilgrim: out of curiosity, did someone force you to ditch the pretty illustrations?
and if so, can we call to complain? :)
(this whole logo brouhaha has me in the complaining mood)
talk to my o'reilly editor
they wanted to maintain their branding
i agreed as long as i could hand them HTML files and never have to touch Microsoft Word
haha. fair enough
true story
yeah, avoiding word is a pretty good trade for just about any other terms they might want to throw at it

I just read the HTML is the new HTML5 blog post…and earlier today I saw the W3C announcement that they're launching a whole branding campaign around the term "HTML5." Doesn't this seem a bit inconsistent and divisive?
the "HTML5" in the W3C logo effort and the WHATWG HTML spec aren't the same thing, so no
in fact that's one of the reasons we changed it, to avoid confusion
There's already a great deal of confusion in the media and even among erudite web developers about what constitutes HTML5, and on that basis I agree with WHATWG's decision.
cool

What concerns me is that just as web standards have finally reached a level of universal appeal and compliance, the two bodies that define them have gone in diametrically opposite directions with terminology (and to some extent, standards defining methodology).
to be fair, the w3c hasn't changed direction
and the whatwg changed direction last year (actually in late 2009), we just didn't change the name until today
Yes, true.
in practice i don't think the directions are really incompatible -- we're still working together on the specs for example
is there a page/blog/place one can get a definitive answer to all this inconsistency? wouldn't that help clear some things up?
though i do think the w3c should join us in the version-less world :-)
wirepair: i'm trying to update the faq, what question should i add? not sure what's unclear :-)
how about... "The media seems really unclear on what HTML5 is and how it relates to newer web technology, what specificially designs HTML5 and how is it different than the whatwg HTML branding?"
something like that ;)
s/version less/revision bases/ i guess
Hixie: are e.g., dropzone="f:text/plain f:text/html" and dropzone="s:text/plain f:text/plain" meant to valid?
err designates
wirepair: let me update the current qs in the faq and then i'll ping you again and see if it answers the question
oh i'm not saying i'm confused
i'm saying the journalists are
i think it's pretty simple tbh ehe
wirepair: i'll ping you and you can see if you think they'll be less confused :-)
sure :)
MikeSmith: yes
ok
thanks
MikeSmith: first one accepts text files and html files dragged in, second one accepts text selections dragged in and text files dragged in
hey wait this isn't #nerdshitnoonecares about
it isn't...? methinks he was lost.
Hixie: I see -- thanks
Hixie: no, clear to me know
spec is clear
Hixie: just trying to write the checker code for it
now realizes Hixie was replying to dude
heh
Are the WHATWG version of the HTML Living Standard and the W3C version of HTML5 always going to be consistent at least for the parts they have in common?

I understand that they're drawn from the same source document, but I'm also concerned that one or the other version may end up substantially different from the other due to this change in direction, and I wonder what this will mean for implementations in practice.
MikeSmith: :)
benschwarz: ♨
Serenalis: yes, they'll always be consistent (unless one goes way off the rails of course, but then that one will just be ignored)

Thanks for clearing that up, though I think that might be a useful FAQ entry for people who are very concerned on a practical level about writing standards-compliant code and especially convincing skeptical project managers about why that's both important and doable. :P
Hixie, with HTML as a living standard, is the intent that the spec will drive implementations or that implementations will shape the spec?
both
in practice it's always been both for successful specs
http://omghtml5.com/post/2837210354/the-most-standards-compliant-html5-logo

Hixie: I agree. One of the biggest criticisms of W3C specs historically has been that they have been disconnected with reality. This Living Standard approach could fix that. Do you think there's a chance W3C will follow suit?
Also, by the way, sorry for barging in and demanding answers with no preamble! Thanks very much for taking the time to talk, I really do appreciate it.

Serenalis: people who are concerned about writing compliant code are going to write code based on what is implemented in browsers, hopefully; making that be the same as the spec is (so far as I can tell) priority #1 for at least the WHATWG version
Serenalis: happy to answer questions, sorry for the lag in my answers :-) (i'm editing the faq)
also, the people in here seem pretty friendly towards those of us who barge in and talk from time to time
Serenalis: i don't know if the w3c will follow, but i really hope so
so don't worry about it, unless someone says otherwise
Serenalis: it is unfortunately one of the most ingrained things at the w3c, so it might take a while
is there a better definition for namespaces than http://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_namespaces.asp ?
jacobolus: I agree completely. Thanks. :)
https://developer.mozilla.org/en/SVG:Namespaces_Crash_Course needs some copyediting
Is the "What you can do" WHATWG wiki entry still current? I may be interested in getting involved once I get up to speed on the latest.
It'd be nice to contribute meaningfully rather than just asking questions.
it's probably current
haven't checked recently
will do in a minute
still editing the faq

yeah, i'm shocked at how well it went
honestly didn't expect it to be this good

does anyone have any idea of how to program this
i figured it'd be 50/50 at best and that people would come over in due course
a handfull of people expressed dislike, in the comments I saw, but not very strongly even
once I understood the intent, my reaction was kind of like "thank god"
"someone actually is connected with reality finally"
(as an outsider :))
I understand WHATWG has been working this way for a while, but to go public with an announcement was great

I'm going to go ahead and say for the record that I rather strongly dislike the new w3c logo.

MikeSmith: anyway, bugzilla.validator.nu and hsivonen.iki.fi are now back
cool, thanks

something I'm glad I don't have to deal with
OK. I think I found the guilty IP address...
hope it's not mine :)
is reading http://brendaneich.com/2011/01/harmony-of-my-dreams/
ok. the validator is now back, too, with the resource-over-using IP address banned

I wonder why no one has decided that robots.txt must be replaced by some sort of robots.xml

(I sent email to Yandex)
MikeSmith: it seems to me iptables is the wrong tool here and I should take the time to implement some kind of throttling in Validator.nu itself
to dynamically detect IP numbers that make unreasonably frequent request to the Web service APIs
hsivonen: that'd be certainly be nice
benefit others who run their own instances
as a plus
Hixie: looks good :)
i like the full inline references in developers.whatwg.org

although it could leave out the fluff and just have the link text in the references

lol one one eleven
wait, othermaciej points out an article that might suggest P=NP but wasn't there one already that proofed the opposite?
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P_versus_NP_problem#Claimed_solutions ah, that was not accepted yet
annevk: that proof is not widely believed to be valid
s/yet//

There is probably a strong correlation between the number of attempted proofs of a problem and its fame. P?=NP is such a famous problem that the density of claimed solutions in either direction is extremely high. Most pass right under the radar, but the internet is very good on picking up those with slightly above-average credibility
http://bit.ly/gR27Et - HTML LS

The specification that cannot die

It seems like the usual misunderstanding of how browser standards work

overall this went really well I think
"So yeah, will CSS3 become CSS now?"

updated http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/WebAppsTweet to ignore typo and xref fixes
I will call it HTML+
html+ is done already, it expired
Another thing I considered doing was enabling an easy way to get the specification for each specific SVN revision. However, I am not entirely sure how to deal with changing dependencies.
So if html+ expired it's actually just html again, right? Old html.
html++ then
The whole point is that there is no difference!
and then it will be html# or objective-html ?
You should all just be using mathml anyway, this html thing won't catch on
annevk: But html++ means that every person who reads the name gets a unique version number! It is giving ownsership of the spec to the community!
lets put it on github
"You essentially have to treat browsers as a bunch of somewhat sleazy politicians" -- Robin Berjon
and a nice day to you too, Mr Berjon
hsivonen: Is there any context or is this twitter?
jgraham: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-xml/2011Jan/0231.html
Hum. What he actually says is quite reasonable
His phrasing of it is pure flamebait
well, or funny
othermaciej: He was being nice to you really, and just agreeing with hsivonen that you need to test for what's implemented
sure, in context his flamebait was eminently reasonable
annevk: Didn't really register as funny for me. I guess he might have been going for "funny"
though
as far as I can tell his views have shifted somewhat since the SVG days
and are somewhat similar to ours now
fwiw, I was quoting out of context for amusement. I don't disapprove of Robin's email.
annevk: what people get older?
lol @ http://dl.dropbox.com/u/50841/twitter/WhatsNew.png
haha, good one
what is rowspan in wiki syntax?
Whoever came up with the badge builder ought to be shot
I thought we ditched such idiotic badges/images finally.
prepares for a new round of Works with FF/IE and Valid HTML images on pages :(
asmodai: saying that someone ought to be shot isn't really an improvement over the military imagery
found it
asmodai, we ditched idiotic validation badges that made false claims more often than not
hsivonen: Heh, true.
Funny though, if you select those features of the badge builder, it's like HTML5 is growing a Pinoccio nose
I made some more changes to the FAQ
hmm. writing a sanitizer becomes really complicated if you want to decide whether the token becomes an HTML, MathML or SVG element before deciding whether to drop it
maybe it's just not worth it...
maintaining distinct attribute white lists for the three should be easy-ish, though
hsivonen: What is the difficulty?
(I'm not saying there isn't one, just wondering what, specifcally, you find hard)

jgraham: if you drop an element after the tree builder algorithm has run, you need a marker on the stack so that you know to drop the matching end tags but not to drop end tags whose element didn't get dropped
so then you have this sparse stack where some stack nodes are "not really" markers that you can't append children to but that participate in the tree builder algorithm otherwise
it looks to me that those "not really" or "can't use this node as a parent" markers will suck for the AAA and such
so you want to sanitize during parsing rather than serializing?
jgraham: otoh, if you always drop all start and end tag tokens for a given tag name, you don't need to keep track of stuff to match end tags with the start tags
annevk: yes
annevk: and only from the security POV--not from the correctness POV
annevk: On Robin's views changing since  svg days "It wasn't long before mobile SVG implementations also used XML parsers that were a little bit more open-minded " :-)
hsivonen: Is it too much work to probe what namespace a tag will become by inspecting the current state of the treebuilder and knowing what the entry/exit points from foreignContent are?
hsivonen:  is there an existing element name for which you do want to take a different decision, depending on html/mathml/svg, or is this future proofing?
hsivonen: (the big problem I see with speculatively inserting elements and rolling back if they end up in an undesired namespace is around AAA and so)
(I think that would mean you had to snapshot the entire tree rather than just marking the inserted elements)
david_carlisle: I can't think of one from the security POV
david_carlisle: so perhaps I shouldn't even try to have distinct white lists
jgraham: that approach would probably make sense if distinct white lists were actually necessary
hmm comments are getting somewhat off-topic
oh well
anyway, I threw away my complicated code and will try again
this time dropping tokens before the tree builder runs

hsivonen: Presumably the reason would be that future standards bodies might be idiotic enough to invent tag names that are safe in one namespace but not another. Or we might grandfather in a language where, say, <div> means "run this script"
Neither of those would happen in a sane world
annevk, | rowspan=n |, if you didn't find it yet
jgraham: I'm not planning on coding for that scenario
Ms2ger, thanks, I figured it out already
jgraham: that would be the world in which browser makers don't implement image and not tell us for a decade that we have an unknown name clash?
Hixie: !Ping
david_carlisle: < jgraham> Neither of those would happen in a sane world
jgraham: something about logic and doors
david_carlisle: fortunately, image is "safe"
hmm. nested SVG scripts are going to be annoying
hsivonen: yes
hmm. so the list of dangerous well-known HTML elements is script, style, applet, object. Right?
working out which parts of SVG are dangerous is harder
anything that causes a request can be dangerous in a way
Is there a bot to leave Hixie a message?
you can file a bug
Yes, one might imagine organising the code around groups of elements according to their properties
Or just leave the message
annevk: do you mean for detecting that a user read a span with a unique image?
e.g. script_elements, request_elements, etc.
and SVG id references that can go across documents is one collection of pain that makes it hard to know which elements end up requesting stuff based on the element name alone
I just added web stats to the developers.whatwg.org edition…
and now, bed. later all
hsivonen, or somewhat dangerous GET requests
e.g. a blog comment in moderation that fetches logout.php
annevk: a blogging system is full of fail if you can be logged out using GET
no argument there
guess it depends on what you want to do
for email it would be similarly bad
I believe Thunderbird catches those on a different layer
other things that could be potentially problematic are elements the author did not expect commenters to use or be able to use
e.g. if the author has one <header> on his page with some position:absolute styling and a commenter includes that as well...
but I guess it depends on whether this API will be exposed to web content or not whether any of the above makes sense
annevk: good point. that threat isn't being addressed
stuff like <svg><script><script><h1> is very annoying
heh, Julian thinks we changed the name because we are angry with the HTML5 logo
http://www.heise.de/ix/meldung/Aus-HTML-5-wird-der-lebende-Standard-HTML-1172423.html
hsivonen, it seems filtering the DOM would give much better results
hsivonen, also, if we want this at the parser layer, should this be part of the parsing section?
annevk: it sure starts looking like it doesn't make sense to recommend this function for non-browser users of the parser
and yeah, I'm starting to suspect whether it makes sense to do this in the parser even in the browser case
though for perf, it kinda sucks to build a DOM fragment, run a filter on it and then insert it
Is this ever a performance-critical operation?
Philip`: dunno
<svg><script><foreignObject><h1>Hi! is annoying, too

I notice that most (all?) of the little annotations in the margin of the HTML5^H spec say that there are 0 tests and 0 demos for a feature, and nothing written about "implementation status"; is there actually some place where such tests/demos would reside, linked from the spec? aren't there plenty of parts that *do* have tests one place or another around the web?
The tests/demos can be anywhere - someone just needs to update the spec to point to them all
is there any good coordinated place showing what has tests, what needs tests, etc.?
No
http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Testsuite has links to various things

it seems like this is a task that could be pretty easily distributed: "write 1-2 test about one of these features"; would be more productive as a discussion than flameouts about nomenclature and so forth
then again, maybe no one would be interested in writing a test or two
It'd probably be good to coordinate work in the HTML WG testing group rather than having everything as ad hoc as it has been
jacobolus, there are a few that do have some tests written and linked from those annotations.
I guess there's also the big problem that someone (not volunteering, for sure) would have to do the organizing/coordination
from memory, the video element has a couple.
(There's some (slow) progress in that direction currently)
jacobolus: A person writing 1-2 tests wouldn't really be scalable to what the spec requires, since it'll need tens of thousands of tests
jacobolus: The HTML TEts TF already exists. The main problems are a) getting people to write tests and b) getting the right metadata to link the TCs to the right parts of the spec
fair enough
Philip`: fair enough

and the overhead of teaching people how to write good test cases and reviewing them and maintaining them etc means you really need someone to take responsibility for developing a coherent set of tests for a whole section of the spec, I think
else it'll be unmanageable
jacobolus: The only well tested part of the spec is <canvas> where a) was solved by Philip` writing all the tests and B0 was solved by Philip` writing a system for annotating the spec
i.e. someone needs to make it their full-time job
jacobolus: There are surprising;y few places you can get paid to spend all your time writing spec tests
In fact I don't know of any
that doesn't seem surprising
I'm pretty sure such a position is obtainable
jacobolus: Yeah, that seems like the most efficient way to get the work done, but I suppose that doesn't help much if nobody is in a position to do that :-(
It does mean that as a strategy starting with "1) assume we will get a full time coordinator" is a losing proposition
e.g. with Mozilla or Google
seems like it'd take a substantial amount of work to even try to consolidate the tests which exist and link them to relevant spec sections
annevk: Maybe, but the evidence is that neither Mozilla nor Google *actually* employ anyone to do that
yes, because nobody is interested in it
In fact neither are particularly active at all in writing tests for HTML
but the result is that it's sort of impossible to figure out what parts are tested and what parts aren't
It sounds like browser testing people spend most of their time debugging browser-specific bugs and writing browser-specific tests, instead of standards tests
right
Is that unavoidable?
it does seem like a wasted duplication of effort, no?
no, but it requires some amount of investment
into a framework that can be shared, that people are willing to use
We do write quite a lot of standards tests
and that shows some reasonable return of investment
But there is inevitably also a component of doing browser-specific work
And that turns out to be a rather large component
I have written tests, but there's hardly any contribution from elsewhere
e.g. for XMLHttpRequest
maybe the bar to entry is too high, but I have not even been contacted
Since the job description is not "write tests" but "help us ship a good browser"
and while other browsers might start using the tests, they are hesitant (to say the least) to convert their own
tl:dr standardizing test infrastructure is tough
and sharing tests is too
Sharing tests is generally not that bad if the recievee is prepared to do all the integration work
jgraham, Mozilla does write a lot of HTML tests, we just don't submit them ;)
Ms2ger: That is the same thing :)
Only from your POV :)
Well from everyone's POV
Apart from yours
jacobolus: apparently you need to buy t-shirts with the HTML5 logo on them to get this testing thing sorted out
has his doubts that will help
hsivonen: is that the W3C version of a middle school bake sale?
maybe the spec could do in-line advertising. "the canvas element, brought to you by Nabisco"
jacobolus: It seems to be. My idea of a real bake sale, with the HTML5 logog on big cakes and all the sub-logos on cupcakes has so far failed to gain any traction
Even when I suggested that we dress up in vinatge military gear to do the selling
damn
and get a brass band clad in HTML5-spandex
On an entirely different topic, does anyone know if, and by how much, faster it is to draw to Xvfb than to real X?
apart from attributes that contain URL, are there dangerous attributes that don't start with "on"?
hsivonen, autofocus
hsivonen, srcdoc
actually, maybe srcdoc is harmless
no, only harmless when sandbox is defined iirc
annevk: good point on autofocus
annevk: what's dangerous with srcdoc? it's in a different origin, right?
what counts as "dangerous"?
othermaciej: stuff that would allow script to run in the wrong origin when the markup is inserted into a different-origin doc
oh, and style is a special case, of course
is srcdoc in a different origin by default?
if the attacker can control all the attributes on an iframe element, then srcdoc is indeed dangerous
I thought it wasn't
but then, so is src
src is excluded already as it contains a URL
any attribute that takes a URL and happens to contain a javascript: URL is probably dangerous
annevk: huh. I thought the whole point of involving an iframe was to put srcdoc into a different origin
othermaciej: what's the attack?
hsivonen, I think that is only true for <iframe srcdoc=test sandbox>
srcdoc can be in a unique origin if you sandbox the iframe
othermaciej: what's the attack that makes srcdoc dangerous if all attributes controlled that is?
hsivonen: I don't know what threat you are defending against, you said "allow script to run in the wrong origin"
but srcdoc iframes can be same-origin with the parent and can run script
annevk: what's the point of srcdoc without sandboxing?
Paul: some in my group may be interested in this
so can iframes with a javascript: src
same-origin srcdoc seems like trouble. what's the point of ever allowing srcdoc to be same-origin? why use an iframe at all in that case?
Bruce: I missed the point of what a class attribute would accomplish, an input box needs more complicated data, if your have markup for that and allows that in your schema
othermaciej: yeah, URL attributes all need special attention
what's the use case here? are you trying to filter html by blacklisting?
david_carlisle: are you in the wrong window?
oops sorry in mathml wg telecon..... :-)
don't understand these tab things, bye
http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bankoski-vp8-bitstream
annevk: interesting choice of venue
hmm. Intended status: Informational
it was also submitted on Jan 6
bit weird
This specification is made available under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 License [4].
Wait, what?
I would have expected that to turn up sooner
does the IETF let you put your choice of license on an RFC? I thought you had to assign them copyright
"Copyright (c) 2011 IETF Trust and the persons identified as the document authors.  All rights reserved." on page one, and CC-BY on page 148
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Request_for_Comments#Status_.22informational.22

Versions somewhat implies "incompatible". I think the idea with levels is that you can only level-up i.e. get new features that you didn't have before
Or at least implies "mechanism of marking which version you are using"
I don't know if that's the meaning everyone would draw from the terms, but sure, barring minor inconsistencies, that's true.
the idea is that with levels the difference is only the feature set
CSS needs doctypes
not the functionality of the features
i.e. once #fff is introduced it will mean white from that point on and nothing else
no future level can change that
but it does not matter too much either way
Unless we determine it was a really bad idea and no browser does it.
then it would not end up in a REC anyway
the "process" deals with that already
But yeah, whatever.  CSS is level-less, except for the 2.1/everything after distinction.  Individual modules are still levelled.  Same diff.
